criteria: Understanding and application of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Ability to interpret integrals as antiderivatives
descriptions: No understanding of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus is demonstrated.
Demonstrates a very limited understanding of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Cannot apply it.
Shows some understanding of the theorem but struggles to apply it correctly in simple cases.
Demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of the theorem and can apply it in basic problems, but may make mistakes.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of the theorem and can apply it effectively in most problems.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of the theorem, can apply it effectively and creatively in complex problems, and can explain it clearly.
Shows no ability to interpret integrals as antiderivatives.
Struggles to interpret integrals as antiderivatives.
Can interpret integrals as antiderivatives in very simple cases with significant errors.
Can interpret integrals as antiderivatives in basic cases, but may struggle with more complex scenarios.
Can effectively interpret integrals as antiderivatives in a variety of problems.
Demonstrates mastery in interpreting integrals as antiderivatives in diverse and complex situations, and can explain the connections clearly.
No attempt to provide proof or justification is made.
Attempts to provide proof or justification are unclear and lack logical reasoning.
Provides some justification, but steps are not clear and may contain logical errors.
Provides adequate justification for most steps, but may have minor gaps in reasoning.
Provides clear and logical justification for all steps.
Provides rigorous and insightful justification for all steps, demonstrating a deep understanding of the underlying concepts.
